title: How to force yourself to write your college essay - Quora

response.answer_text: The most common way to incentivize yourself to do something you’d rather not do is to promise yourself a reward once you’ve completed the task. It doesn’t need to be anything major (e.g. a new car) - just something you know you will look forward to an enjoy. The deeper question is working out why you are procrastinating in the first place. I’ve suffered from this most of my life, and still do, and I’m still not sure what drives it. To a degree, I think it’s related to over-thinking things, and a desire for perfection, but I’m not 100% confident that’s what it is. Another tactic is to timebox your work - set yourself a deadline, or if necessary, a series of sessions if it’s a long essay (or maybe one session to to the necessary research and another session to actually do the writing). It can also be helpful to use a kitchen timer, or similar - but the sound of time ticking away is what helps, because it’s a constant reminder that your deadline is approaching. It is also recommended not to try to work for more than about an hour at a time (at most), after which you should take a short (e.g. 5 minutes) break before getting back to work. You may find that listening to instrumental music while you work - it does for some people, but not everybody.

If you first make a good plan, you won’t have to force yourself to write the essay — you’ll just execute step by step and feel confident along the way that you’re saying what you want to say, the way you want to say it. That’s the mission. First make a list of the required and supplemental/optional essays you’ll have to write. There will be some overlap, so you don’t have to reinvent the wheel for every essay. Some of the essay questions won’t have been released yet for 2019–20, but those will roll out in the next few months. The Common App essay topics are staying the same as last year, so you can already find out what those are for 2019–20. Then figure out where there’s overlap, and where you might want to swap out essays (e.g. my Common App essay would work really well for the School X Supplemental essay, so I’ll use that one for the Supplemental and write a different one for the Common App essay for School X). You can change up what Common App essay/topic you submit school by school, so take advantage of that flexibility. Once you have your list of topics (and which ones you’ll be using for which school), identify what it is they’re actually asking for. Read the questions carefully. Whatever it is they’re asking (an experience that changed your perspective on something, your favorite book, or quirky ones like “how is Plato like Play-Doh”), remember that underneath they’re always asking about *you*. So you are always the subject, no matter how they ask the question. Sometimes that takes the form of you writing about your experiences/observations, or it might be about more indirect through something external (like a book), in which case it’s your opinion or insight that makes it about you. Either way, don’t lose sight of the true (and constant) topic. How you write it — the voice, the tone — also makes it about you. Even if it’s a particular story that someone else might cover as well, what makes it unique is that only you could have written it the way you did, and it has your voice, and it sounds like you. That means that whatever it is that you write about, it has to be *specific* and *personal*. If it’s a “Why School X” essay (which you’ll often find in the school supplemental essays), you want to signal to the school why you and the school are such a good fit. It’s not enough just to say as much; you need to back up that assertion with examples and specific reasons. That means you need to know enough about the school to make a convincing argument: the academic culture, the location, the learning environment, the kinds of students they have, a particular department or major that interests you, etc. Be as specific as you can and namecheck those specific things so that you couldn’t say the same thing about its peer schools (which would make the essay too generic). You don’t have to have figured out your life goals before you apply to college, but you do need to have some goals for the college experience itself. What is it you actually want to get out of college? Does it line up with what that college has to offer? If you’re finding it hard to connect the two, that might be a sign that that college isn’t a good fit, for you or for the school. Your college list might even change in the process, and that’s OK. You can focus on career interests or academic interests or both. Include some goals for things about college life that excite you, but keep academics front and center, because college is ultimately an academic enterprise. Also important: ditch the 5-paragraph structure that they teach you for papers in school. This isn’t a school paper (even if your English teacher doubling as your college counselor might be encouraging you to write it like one — no). In a personal essay this short, you do not need an intro (paragraph 1), three points (paragraphs 2–4), and then a conclusion (paragraph 5). That’s not how you tell a story, and a college application essay is fundamentally about telling a story. The 5-paragraph structure is deathly dull for application essays — they honestly made we want to stick a fork in my eyes when I was reading thousands of them back to back. Begin with an opener that grabs the reader, and end with a closer that releases a reader. Under no circumstances should you use an introduction that is a preview of the essay or a conclusion that is a summary of the essay. That’s the 5-paragraph standard coming back from the grave. Kill it. And finally, don’t let the grown-ups in your life, who are probably more risk averse and haven’t been admissions officers, scrub the voice from the essay that is distinctly yours. That goes for topics too, because teenagers don’t sound like middle aged people (I know, right?). For example, I once read an essay about a student who founded the model UN club at his school and he was proud of being a “change agent” and of all the “sweat equity” he had put into it; I’m guessing dad had a heavy hand in the essay. Don’t let that happen. Your voice gives the essay personal authenticity. That’s so important. The admissions officer wants to get to know you, not your parents (or whomever). I have a LOT to say on the subject but I hope that gives you something motivates you — if done right, this should even feel a bit fun, not something to dread. :)
